C69786E85325413C893D5647EAC8C454.description: A speaker's vocal delivery (e.g., volume, rate, enunciation) and physical actions (e.g., posture, gestures, movement) can enhance or undermine a presentation.

8E556065FCBF49DEB48A56AE127206F4.description: Communicate clearly and effectively, using appropriate verbal and nonverbal techniques.

7F01DC71D290455386EB7B4BE29C8935.description: Audiences provide verbal and nonverbal cues, and effective speakers use those cues to adjust elements such as pacing, volume, and tone throughout a presentation.

BA0115D64B254710A59BCA9BD017FFB2.description: Effective speakers consider the audience's likely reaction to the topic and develop a presentation that engages the audience without compromising the message.

92F8ABC3F1BD4C5995BC8698BCD5B3E6.description: Demonstrate an awareness of the audience during both the planning and delivery of a presentation, and make adjustments based on the audience's responses.

4B241A80B09048E18EECDEC080E4F610.description: Visual and multimedia aids require purposeful selection in order to engage listeners and clarify information without creating a distraction or communication barrier.

1F0169CD85AB43A4A6C19AFD41EC54A7.description: Incorporate effective visual and multimedia tools to enhance the presentation and achieve the intended effect.

257E6AFE0D49468D9FB2F9169583F962.description: The formality, length, and overall style of a presentation are influenced by the speaker's subject and purpose, the audience's background, and the occasion that prompted the presentation.

2F9780ED38BC48E885DE480BF4E70429.description: Determine the purpose for communication and select an appropriate format.

B69AB42D4B45433791C4D157BD31E37C.description: Effective speakers design and deliver presentations according to their subject, purpose, audience, and occasion.

5882BD324E0B4E12ABD751CAC2C68846.description: When considering positions presented by others, the listener should assess the soundness of others' reasoning and the strength of evidence presented.

839EC266C55343D98F159565A6D6C9A3.description: Effective academic discussions include substantial evidence that adds to the credibility of the speaker and the significance of the discussion.

5EBDA55D60EB47B0AFB59FEEE46C7BDB.description: Cite relevant evidence and evaluate the evidence presented by others.

AD6C152CB9284C9AB8972B71BA5F3B79.description: Listening to others' opinions requires attending carefully, responding appropriately, reflecting on what was shared, and weighing others' ideas against one's own position.

B2FD27CDDD234ABCBA5D60ACDB5AC54F.description: Creating talking points prior to a discussion helps the speaker stay focused and present ideas clearly.

19040F0CA52D4940A4B593BDAB883F52.description: Preparing for academic conversations requires considering topics and/or texts and developing a point of view.

43B9E92769D04B76934E8802F8967772.description:
Extend the conversation around an idea, topic, or text
by formulating questions and recognizing the claims and perspectives of others.

C1382478E5D04C3E8F143B2CC0F00C5B.description: Academic discourse requires collaboration to advance and deepen understanding of topics or texts.

65C2C441DB5D4D5C809AA778410E2936.description: Standard citation formats assist readers and provide a means for fact-checking and conducting additional research.

12A1AE167D434B69A6B46B627D694814.description: Writers must also properly credit sources and ideas that exist in formats other than traditional print (e.g., images, video clips, music, personal interviews).

2D0728045AA64EE88D71A0F65A780F2A.description: Evidence must be cited appropriately to acknowledge others' words and ideas.

E7F5D531208944CA84C71416C80E507B.description:
Attend to the ethical responsibilities of research, including the presentation of citations and references in
a specified, standard format (e.g., APA, MLA) and the use of appropriate and legal sources for texts, images, and sound.

E1356078233045CBB121D5F11567EAB2.description: Direct quotations can add credibility, but they should be used judiciously to ensure that the researcher provides sufficient analysis of a quotation and how it relates to his or her central claim.

B1D856B2C57742A99E2FBBA9266D5ED5.description: Whether summarizing, paraphrasing, or quoting, researchers must acknowledge the sources of words and ideas.

3611AA46ED5B4F8F9C75093B29AF332D.description: Summarize, paraphrase, or directly quote others' words appropriately and effectively.

FBF24BF6619F486B89E21759BFB358D5.description: Sharing research goes beyond simply restating findings to include interpretation, significance, and implications for additional research.

177908CB7CFD4116A9DDD1977FE70587.description: It is important to distinguish the researcher's point of view from that of experts in the field.

B5CF5D6175344BBEBFED56DCDF38EEBA.description: Research findings can be conveyed through a variety of methods (e.g., reports, data tables, social media, videos, spreadsheets).

70C8BBFFE76A414F8D5B8F6BB20CDAB2.description: Communicate findings and their significance, incorporating written, spoken, and multimedia approaches according to task, purpose, and audience.

D8F575D53DC2403FA222F065BDF9E1D3.description: A claim is the researcher's own answer to the research question or problem, and it is grounded in credible evidence found during the process.

D5A58B585AE44DFD89B51D41FE2A328B.description: Make an independent claim that addresses the research question or problem and is supported by the findings.

02222A6D00624B708B9A29E1312C1E88.description: Research presentations and reports include new findings as well as a synthesis of the prior research of others.

04B56EF478AB4804B59BBC669FBDA10F.description: Source bias must be considered within the research process.

2EC949059A30477D944BCA6EDEB0A485.description: Sources must be evaluated based on established criteria (e.g., authenticity, accuracy, merit, fact or opinion, direct relationship to the topic).

3F9CE2FB1C7544CBA1BF6BB40BE272D6.description: Determine the credibility, reliability, and relevancy of selected sources.

E67E3C858D8F46A9A7BEBABAF6F41434.description: Effective research requires integrating the findings of multiple sources accurately and strategically.

8F003388E36C4904ABD77C7F65C5EC07.description: Researchers may rely on a wide variety of primary and other sources (e.g., collected data, books, journal articles, websites, video footage, historical documents).

81150F79A4CD4BAF8FE98347363AFBE0.description: Gather, evaluate, and synthesize evidence from multiple authoritative sources (e.g., print, digital, multimedia) to address the research question or problem.

E02FC42376B84A32A3B23D3B869DBB7C.description:
Preliminary research can confirm, challenge, or expand the
initial problem, question, or idea.

174A57A8AE964D3A8B1DF1FF78F56F40.description: Research can be formal or informal, sustained, and on the spot.

180CCF5E83C643B49D845F3D56803019.description: Identify a problem, idea, or central question and complete preliminary readings to determine the purpose, scope, and process of the research.

FB3325579EFC426F96B79CFA0C1CAED3.description: Research is a powerful, recursive process used to gain knowledge, solve problems, make informed decisions, and enhance understanding.

40D185508EBB47518C8D3CEE2D4C543E.description: Deliberately defying conventions of standard English may influence voice, tone, and rhetorical effect.

6F0201475A4844F190E2455CD8416AB5.description:
Writers consider the flexibility of the genre (e.g., poetry,
dramatic dialogue) as they make decisions about adhering to conventions.

47B83B5F0CB14B709DC95562C2481A5E.description: Understand the ways in which language choices can be made to achieve intended effects.

C39417C40A61463EABD06033AAB9983D.description: Inappropriate shifts in verb tense can disorient a reader.

69656C78310F453D8AD50BD53898EA2C.description: To ensure clarity, there should be agreement between subjects and verbs and between pronouns and their antecedents.

5115D3E9FC4B4B83B44C7A14C8BB1D04.description: Compose or revise language to ensure proper agreement and appropriate verb tense.

B93F3B78B9EC4B2EA1AE753D5FB1915F.description: Modifying phrases need to be appropriately placed within a sentence so that readers can clearly understand what they are modifying.

5EADE41FBB754B18829E51119504B0EB.description: Complex sentences require the use of appropriate punctuation, parallel structure, and coordinating and subordinating conjunctions.

7673BA426F4D49EA97437D65ED8A598D.description: Capitalization and punctuation can indicate sentence boundaries and clarify the relationships between and among words, phrases, and clauses within a sentence.

AAFAFCC1F6104468B27D168A671BF43E.description: Compose or revise language to ensure sentences are grammatically correct and that their internal structures provide clarity.

362057981F4E493CBEDB32B2214F322E.description: Conventions of standard English are used to aid the reader's understanding, and authors may use or defy these conventions to achieve different stylistic effects.

33B8595F449A4846A248FBC1E1DD6660.description: Linguistic diversity across dialects and registers contributes to the power and richness of language.

EF4FB5C3B143448C91DF4C2F9BB2615A.description: Word choice and language patterns should be appropriate for the subject, audience, occasion, and purpose of the writing or presentation.

EF1CDF1837944159BD46759230C9C08D.description: Varying sentence structures can maintain the reader's interest, enhance voice, and contribute to fluency.

6AE81DA844CD419DA44E903B65DC54CC.description: Compose or revise language to ensure that word choice and language patterns are consistent with the intended style, voice, register, and tone of a text or presentation.

A34845F17E064626B0D4083328816AB4.description: Although writers may use repetition as a rhetorical strategy, redundancy should be avoided.

128B8A4D389E46599357946F9F2EC686.description: Concise writing avoids wordiness and instead relies on the use of the strongest and most effective words.

05BFB365EDBE42429E46B67CC55BEA30.description: Related words may appear synonymous or interchangeable, but there is value in choosing the best word to achieve a particular rhetorical effect.

5AABD9F2F36E4FE6840BF67A99B7D7B4.description: LO 3.2A Compose or revise language to honor precision and economy in word choice.

81DEAF62C7A04EA69720A5D63E85EA9A.description: Precise word choice and compelling language patterns can stir the thoughts, emotions, and actions of readers.

386C6E3FD2AE4C66AE5615010DCF5056.description: Usage guides can offer guidelines for addressing grammar and frequently misused words and phrases.

3A4C56188ADC46B69DA1BB3BC3EFC3D9.description: A thesaurus can help a writer choose the most appropriate word for a particular usage.

19E3DAE7D2514021A16D4E54626E4BB1.description: Online dictionaries can provide definitions as well as a multitude of authentic sentence examples that can guide usage of unfamiliar or multiple-meaning words.

1D927C79D4CC4D96B308246C0CBD9FDA.description: Research a word's various meanings by consulting online and print reference sources (e.g., dictionaries, thesauri, usage guides).

788402BA75344A519FA104AFAE639B84.description: Recognizing patterns in morphology can help readers see how words are related to one another.

1E8E92BFA06F4293A1D8D337045C8F29.description: Recognizing patterns in word endings (e.g., -ly, -tion, -ify ) can contribute to a reader's understanding of a word's part of speech.

74E7B8C34B524E04AE4F35256831C743.description: Applying knowledge of roots and affixes (prefixes and suffixes) can help a reader deduce the meanings of unfamiliar words.

24DC3263C6AB453295D2F243145B5BF3.description: Analyze a word based on its parts (base word and affixes), and relate its morphology to its meaning.

FEC676A5866D4D2EAC28A5C59253E7AA.description: A word's literal and figurative meanings can influence meaning simultaneously, enabling the reader to interpret the word in multiple ways.

D41703B76DCD40D8BEE810D49F9C126C.description: Words with similar denotations can have significantly different connotations.

EA4B8B9FF88E4C8A8750CD4E4FA5F6AF.description: A word's nuanced meaning is often dependent on the context in which it is used.

87AD9D3A1A1B46D9B40BC4EABE49E181.description: Use context clues to infer the meaning of multiple-meaning or unfamiliar words.

373F936F3A014B2482CB96EE7D7D2A04.description: Critical readers develop a sense of word consciousness that motivates them to investigate word meanings.

CE2394D3205D49609EEAA68F8D9C6F39.description: Word choice helps convey a particular voice with its own syntax, diction, and tone.

E2598034163A42B68451C1A62FD2B056.description: Writers can use language to directly or indirectly indicate shifts in time and setting.

408D8DC871E440F18229BDC92FC09AF1.description: Vivid descriptions, imagery, and figurative language draw the reader into the narrative.

30A6A2C11AF84CB7ABAAE993F2A7E740.description: Use carefully selected language to help the reader imagine or share the experience conveyed in the narrative.

009C1F2C239442698E44ED164F3C799C.description: Meaning can be enhanced when objects, settings, or characters are used symbolically to represent larger ideas.

B2047664084C4A09969779496474C79A.description: Characters and events are developed through the use of techniques such as description, dialogue, pacing, and reflection.

D5D8B61F51754D408FD9172082261871.description: Whereas plot forms the storyline (the events, conflicts, and actions of the characters), themes are those meaningful ideas that surface through the telling of the story.

6C8867CA84C44557B7A62340DC92652B.description: Use a variety of techniques to advance plot, theme, and the evolution of character(s).

34E96109EDFA4C27AD4342823A4C32B9.description: Third-person narration can be objective and/or omniscient, but a first-person narrator can also be a central figure in the story, so reliability and perspective must be evaluated.

F9E9B70467164CF18DB23D65CB94B358.description: Consistent first-person or third-person points of view are the most common narrative perspectives; however, some authors prefer to establish multiple or shifting points of view.

84177E75CC774B3290D5CBD9458E1747.description: A narrator provides the lens through which a real or imagined story is told.

44F516E13EEB4062A3F66C6361E7D031.description: Establish a narrative point of view.

C4D4DB8D32824C14A28031B54EF27C51.description: Writing a narrative allows a writer to convey experience, share perspective, or deepen their own understanding.

2CED1EE74342419BBC9B19C64BFC6B3C.description: The writer's own position, voice, and style should be supported but not overshadowed by textual evidence.

34761014B437445D9E4131C34699460B.description: Smooth and meaningful transitions are vital to create a logical and cohesive progression of ideas.

6FAD661B5F2B4181AF8E7DE50458B05E.description: Precise word choice and sentence variety can focus the reader's attention, convey an intended tone, and present a convincing analysis.

E9250E10059B4CC394C62D4FD328C650.description: Use an appropriate style and carefully selected language to strengthen an analysis.

3E94190F003F4078A40E07B093D8B437.description: Citations distinguish the writer's ideas and words from those of the work being analyzed and from those of additional sources.

75E4AE0D5446438AA98EA80CE194A4FA.description: Literary analysis focuses on how narrative elements and/or stylistic features interact to convey meaning.

175CCF62D4E64F3F85181C0E46E5FE65.description: Rhetorical analysis focuses on how a writer has crafted an argument and how its relevant features (e.g., rhetorical appeals, word choice, use of evidence and reasoning) contribute to its overall effect.

AFFDBD3B245D49C0AD025DE117801920.description: The nature of the evidence in a textual analysis will depend on the genre of the text.

46CE2D84C64E488B82CBF5D2501F5CB1.description: Select and incorporate relevant and compelling evidence to support a thesis.

C86DBEBD67D341C7BF59164BC4CECA44.description: A writer should make explicit connections between evidence and thesis.

F696E1EA2FDE450EACA5915A78BBFBFC.description: The presentation of textual evidence in an analysis does not necessarily mirror the chronology or order of the original text.

0BF6EA3325BB4D89BFCEBFA76EA06C91.description: Organize ideas and evidence to effectively develop and support a thesis.

C7FE04275D904EA5864FDEE390A8B7B2.description: A well-written thesis statement acts as a lens through which the reader can interpret the analysis.

B1CD6D9E086340D3AC4E6D6730365E51.description: Many writers first develop a working thesis that may be replaced, revised, or tweaked during the writing process.

68C94996862242E480771615C9702345.description: A thesis statement expresses a precise claim that will require analytical support and not mere summary to further develop.

714A38AA45924FBABDDF44865240C2C3.description: Assert a precise central claim that establishes the relationship between a work's features and overall meaning.

38D3A840600A4836AF5F732B5281AC78.description: Writing an analysis requires interpreting the relevant details and features of a work and explaining their relationship to the meaning of the work as a whole.

2F935034651746EDA5F215A61E28C0D4.description: Writers use a variety of rhetorical devices (e.g., repetition, metaphor, irony) to help the reader understand and affirm the writer's position.

04801B4EDD414F5E91C28E9BE1FC9F60.description: Precise word choice and sentence types and length help writers capture the attention of readers, convey an intended mood or tone, and present a convincing argument.

2B6A89311B2A4277BEC12B52AA81001D.description: Rhetorical appeals to logos, ethos, and pathos are often used to enhance an argument.

5C2125D21DBE40E9B060FD8A2DEA66DE.description: Use carefully selected language, syntax, and stylistic and persuasive elements to strengthen an argument.

A13E42BF5E9A4AD0A0C0612D132E472C.description: Addressing a counterclaim often includes providing compelling evidence to support and refute it.

AF75302AAA75407CA1B0FDD92304D28F.description: Anticipating and acknowledging conflicting points of view can add credibility to an argument.

E9D6A092FDC9402DAC4D678F430F8BE1.description: Evidence must be cited appropriately to acknowledge others' ideas.

843DF1E66D7740B79FAA50650A52CC37.description: Evidence can take many forms, including facts, quotations, examples, anecdotes, quantitative evidence, and summaries of others' ideas.

58BD4B019BF24D468A4FB7E7A4F076A0.description: Support a claim by selecting and incorporating evidence that is relevant, sufficient, and convincing.

DE09B6B429034EE79111C5C99B270EDC.description: Arguments often follow organizational patterns that a writer may emulate.

38FE21865F364DF6A933F4FAC1448AE5.description: Reasoning is the glue that holds an argument together and connects ideas in a logical sequence.

E096779FE65641858AD3F01F6F8BE09F.description: An effective argument contains a compelling lead-in and closing that are relevant to the purpose and audience.

D420497DE78D4A5A9E9CC6D884160221.description: Develop a line of sound reasoning and choose an organizing structure to convey that reasoning to the reader.

A432897D524145309037B990219119BB.description: There are ethical considerations (e.g., civic responsibilities, accuracy of facts) associated with influencing an audience's opinions or actions.

1A45D7E764FE487480CDBBC075A1D2C5.description: Academic writing requires engaging with the ideas of others while recognizing one's own opinions and biases.

4E062B645B414007923292C5EC19C096.description: A central claim expresses the writer's belief or point of view about a topic.

2C1DD92AB22E40F5A5D9913A8EA98FBF.description: Constructing an argument is a crucial skill with importance in academic, civic, social, and workplace settings.

77894CFA76FE4F09AD566F77D8F6295C.description: An important part of the writing process is determining the most relevant and compelling ideas to pursue.

B4003F27F2EC400888D39F3C3B3FF6F6.description: There are a variety of ways to generate ideas (e.g., free writing, graphic organizers, academic discussions, research, text readings).

21CCA673B82C4522A07501305B2444E8.description: Gather and generate a variety of ideas, and select the most appropriate based on the purpose of the composition.

284A1205E0DC4FAD8CF671659D6DA35A.description: Effective writers are skillful in composing in multiple genres and knowing when to blend genres to achieve intended purposes.

682E5E0E9C9D4BDBB23F1A6616D458F9.description: The audience is the intended reader. Although teachers read student writing, they are not the sole audience.

A6B926D79EAD46C48B8725ED9AC536F2.description: Purpose drives writing; it is what a writer wants his or her reader to witness, believe, or do.

BB9CF11E699B43A59C361A122B19552B.description: Establish a purpose for the composition and make deliberate choices about genre, organization, and language according to the purpose and intended audience

5E852C0B4CC9491DA03600BE7F446CDB.description: Composing is a recursive process that can be used to explore ideas and illuminate concepts for both the writer and the reader.

652CFD93AFA34748A7796285D75332D7.description: Reading multiple texts that address the same idea, subject, or theme may heighten a reader's awareness of divergent perspectives.

07175978030444CFAE6D0D2713322846.description: Texts may build on or challenge the ideas of previously written texts.

87BA3B508BD1496A828D0FE388D62A63.description:
Synthesize ideas from multiple texts and explain how
the texts may convey different perspectives on a common theme or idea.

6593B2625E90427A8C7610B325306642.description: A reader's interpretation of a text may be shaped by their own experiences.

BAF5C06F424049019422393FD53729BC.description: Authors consciously or unconsciously convey or question the cultural values of the time and place in which they are writing.

AF136D9C6C714BF3824E2AE6E4A4D3AA.description: Texts often reflect or address the historical or cultural contexts in which they were written.

88430CAB47F14653BED37B04E565D352.description: Explain the relationship between a text and its historical or cultural context.

7F483694ABBE4599AAF8A4896FD5E51A.description: A text may be read in conversation with other texts or in the broader context in which it was written or read.

08B441A9BA4144209ACDDCA78041B648.description: A particular literary genre may privilege certain structural and stylistic elements.

B13E7C51D8CF4B1CA027FADB6CC5969E.description: Objects, settings, and even characters can have symbolic meaning, and that meaning can develop or shift as the work unfolds.

2AD592E801534722AA9AD8E00011D589.description: An awareness of stylistic features (e.g., figurative language, imagery, syntax, diction) is critical to the appreciation of a work of literature.

11D85F4E456946C38E19869B660DEA17.description:
Analyze how the
writer's use of stylistic elements contributes to a work of literature's effects and meaning.

C210C25BCA45424D8852C4D76D0E3170.description: Literary elements (e.g., character, setting, plot, tone, point of view) may shift or evolve throughout a work of literature, and analyzing those changes results in a deeper understanding of the work as a whole.

925FED7259744894B364844E54F2DCCD.description: The complexity of literature can result in multiple, varied interpretations of theme.

F56B651494444A1CB686B6A5CCE39767.description: Analyze how literary elements interact to develop the central ideas of a work of literature.

4BE51568D8A94D64AB9B5B7641179A96.description: Analyzing literature is a complex task that includes making inferences, examining an author's use of literary and stylistic elements, and drawing conclusions about the meaning of the work as a whole.

77045AF580AD474E9B1B746E6042C6D1.description: The power of an argument's rhetoric can hinge upon effective word choice and syntax.

E4FAEDC1D0BD4479B9C429FFD74C4473.description: Authors select organizational patterns (e.g., cause and effect, compare and contrast, refutation, problem–solution) to contribute to the effectiveness of their arguments.

B757EF902F2C497CA96A37F93C47402E.description: An awareness of the elements of a rhetorical situation (i.e., text, author, audience, purpose[s], and occasion) is critical to the evaluation of an argument.

35F423EE9CB943E29B2AC6FD578EF4C8.description: Explain how the rhetorical features of an argument contribute to its effect and meaning.

C2ED446A2C684244927135488EFC3A1A.description: An argument often acknowledges and responds to a counterclaim.

CAD9CF7685E14A958CCD2CF9857729A3.description: Informational graphics can serve as a source of supporting evidence in an argument.

39C1E759F12B49F780641557F9891330.description: An argument is developed through logical reasoning and supporting evidence.

103CBEC7A7C047DBA9F182AFF85893E2.description: Analyze the development of an argument, evaluating its central claim(s), the soundness of the reasoning, and the relevance and sufficiency of the evidence.

B91FB1D165314C56A67C9B3054DE3F3A.description: Evaluating an argument is a complex task that includes analyzing stated and implied claims, logical reasoning, supporting evidence, and stylistic elements.

8B1A3064042441689945480CF9534C2F.description: Metacognitive reflection (thinking about one's thinking) during the reading process can enhance comprehension.

1469AFD6B7554150A332EDAB025EBFED.description: Active reading strategies (e.g., annotating, outlining, summarizing, questioning, rereading) can facilitate reading complex texts independently and proficiently.

5AE73F5269604D598EAC7290E4EC515D.description: Use a repertoire of active reading strategies appropriate to the text and task

A81B02E414A9404AB11375DD1A3DFBB8.description: An informational graphic or visual element can be read as a text in and of itself and can also contribute to a reader's interpretation of a corresponding text.

9FC90092FBBB45329ACF1C65FA992DEE.description: The structural or stylistic elements of a text often follow the conventions of its genre.

CDC5619E8A88420FA8FDCF16B7BD5F1E.description: Understand how structural, stylistic, visual, and graphic elements of a text (e.g., photographs, charts, graphs, illustrations, headings, fonts) contribute to its meaning.

5859058F492D4E1B9346CEC22ED97A0C.description: An author's purpose may not be stated explicitly and in such cases must be inferred based on textual observations.

F303F6999EF8458DBE1826CB96587F00.description: Critical reading requires reading both with and against the ideas presented in a text.

32F1AFC1E3E3401F87732EDA1D49B40B.description: A text may convey both literal and figurative meanings, which in turn can generate a multitude of interpretations.

BB2955B390BB4281824AA3C3C7A25904.description: Analyze a wide range of texts for multiple meanings.

0EBAA861E91246CC80E2DB10B5F3A6B1.description: Close and critical reading of complex literary and nonfiction texts leads to a deeper understanding of the explicit and implicit meanings of the works.
